In the text we often find 'in Komnzo', 'of Komnzo' etc. (check the whole document, I don't mark this elsewhere). I think this is often superfluous because it is clear that the whole book is about Komnzo.
I suggest replacing 'free pronouns' by 'personal pronouns' (cf. the section titles in this chapter).
It is not clear to me why the term 'adjectivaliser' is used here and elsewhere. Why not simply 'adjectivizer'?
The use of BE vs. AE spelling seems inconsistent. Above 'adjectivaliser' is used (BE), here 'artifact' (AE), rather than 'artefact' (BE).
Consider deleting 'see' here and elsewhere in the manuscript whenever it precedes a section reference.
Check use of hyphen with morpho(-)syntactically throughout the manuscript, sometimes a hyphen is used, sometimes it isn't.
Is this 'n' a typo (see that it doesn't occur in the segmented line below)?
Often 'below' and 'above' is used together with example references and section references. I think this is not needed. Consider deleting.
(NB: I do not mark this in the remainder of the chapter.)

I wonder why such a long abbreviation (MASC) is used for such a common gloss. See that a very short 'F' is used for 'feminine'. Consider using 'M' for 'masculine' (which would require that you gloss the less common middle marker, presently marked as 'M', with e.g. 'MID').
Place the footnote symbol after the full stop.
Sometimes example references are given as 'in (1)', sometimes as 'in example (1)'. I think that the word 'example' is often superfluous. Consider deleting here and elsewhere in the manuscript.
In fact, '(abs) is not only found in (5) but also used in quite a few other example glosses in this manuscript.
Here 'kinterms', elsewhere often 'kin terms'. Be consistent and check the whole manuscript.

Even if it seems obvious, I propose adding a word on why 'masculine' and 'feminine' are chosen as labels for the two gender values. Are most (human/higher animal) referents of female sex feminine and most referents of male sex masculine? Are there exceptions (in the domain of humans/higher animals)?
